problem_text:
A non-empty set θ of formations is called a complete lattice of formations if the intersection of any set of formations in θ belongs to θ and θ has the largest element (with respect to inclusion). If L is a complete lattice, then an element a ∈ L is said to be compact if a ⩽ ⋁X for any X ⊆ L implies that a ⩽ ⋁X1 for some finite X1 ⊂ X. A complete lattice is called algebraic if every element is the join of a (possibly infinite) set of compact elements.
a) Is there a non-algebraic complete lattice of formations of finite groups?
b) Is there a non-modular complete lattice of formations of finite groups?
A. N. Skiba
